basics.name: Dmitry Verkhoturov
basics.label: Senior Site Reliability Engineer
basics.summary:
I am passionate about meaningful alerting and monitoring, troubleshooting, automation, and reliability. I have a decent knowledge of Linux internals, networking, and system design. I work primarily with bare-metal and generic cloud services in all major providers, ones you consider safe from vendor locks like EC2 and S3. At that moment in my career, I'm a cloud builder, not a cloud user.
In recent years I have been programming mainly in Go, and you can find much of my work on my GitHub, https://github.com/paskal. Also, I can write code in Python, TypeScript and Shell and maintain and build upon code written in Ruby, Perl, PHP and Java.
I feel like a fish in a sea of high ambiguity and chaotic environments, where I need to figure out the goals and ways to reach them. I need a lot of responsibility and big problems on the horizon to be interested in my work.
I have three and a half years of team management experience, and I like leading more than managing, and I care a lot about mentoring and succeeding together. My peers consider me a good negotiator, and I have a history of finding working compromises for cross-team problems.

work.name: Booking.com
work.position: Senior Site Reliability Engineer, ABU Reliability
work.summary: Booking is a top 1 internet travel company by market cap. Currently, I'm working in the Accommodations BU, which is responsible for the main services used by our customers and partners.
highlights: I'm working on bringing reliability to the same high bar in the company's most significant and oldest money-generating department.
I'm building a team and processes for the new team members to scale it from three (very senior) to nine people.
I've conducted over 100 technical interviews in 2022, contributing to finding new colleagues and improving the process with feedback and questions changes.
Over my whole time in the company, I have participated in on-call shifts on team and department levels and groups responsible for the Booking.com site working.
I contribute weekly tweaks to processes, code, and documentation within my reach across the company. I'm in the company's top 5 Puppet code contributors each year, starting with the first one.

work.name: Booking.com
work.position: Senior Site Reliability Engineer, Private Cloud Adoption
work.summary: That year I became responsible for onboarding the first biggest internal customers to the Private Cloud platform. The foundation was 95% ready, but we had to alter it according to customers' requirements and build the layer of APIs and interfaces to integrate vendor products with the internal systems. I left the team after dedicated EM and TPM came in and took most of the responsibilities from me, and I lost most of the scope I had.
highlights: I had my TPM hat on, led negotiations with the customers, and ensured that the project was mainly on track and the team of seven people did things that got us closer to the goal.

I've written and reviewed a dozen of Architecture Design Records. One of the main challenges we had to solve with the team was managing complexity and distributing it between customers and us and within services and logical layers on our side.
The team had outstanding technical capabilities, and I could concentrate on development direction and building trust with the customers rather than

work.name: Booking.com
work.position: Site Reliability Engineer, Image Service and Email Infrastructure
work.summary: I was responsible for a year for image serving and transactional email delivery infrastructure
highlights: Reduced Keep The Lights On activities (e.g. maintenance and toil, not contributing to the product) from 90% to 60% within two teams I was working with and one sister team, primarily through automation.
Drove migration from pet to cattle approach to infrastructure for multiple teams and helped them decrease the noise-to-signal alerting ratio.

work.name: Booking.com
work.summary: For the first year and a half, I provided security guardrails for cloud migration. The mission was to provide a cloud environment to internal customers that were secure yet not crippled. My contribution was researching and building the technical measures necessary for SOx compliance and auditability and keeping up with hundreds of developers making their products.

work.name: IPonWeb
work.summary:
BidSwitch is a product of IPonWeb. It allows participation in RTB auctions with many partners with minimal technical efforts and spending advertising budgets on the highest quality traffic.
I switched the team and position to find new challenges and get acquainted with new technologies: Jenkins + Groovy, GitLab, Kubernetes + helm.
I set up Prometheus monitoring for team infrastructure, wrote a lot of Groovy code and tests, and developed dozens of internal and open-source helm charts.

work.name: IPonWeb
work.summary: IPonWeb (300+ employees) provides technology for the advertising industry, Real-Time Bidding auctions in particular â€” the company handles millions of transactions every minute, with terabytes of data stored and processed daily. I created and managed a team of engineers, ensuring the company's service operations 24/7/365.
highlights: Reduced daily company-wide incident alerts from 200 to 5-10.
Developed applications/modules in Python, Puppet (+Ruby), and SQL.
Deployed and maintained applications in Amazon and Google cloud services.
Part of my work was implementing changes, and I know how to make others do what I need. I interacted with every team in the company regarding the introduction of improvements.
Created and integrated on-duty incident management procedures (how, when, and what to do when you're on-call) based on ITIL, by which duty shifts have been operating since then.
Created a new team of eight people in three cities.
I wrote a ton of documentation and recorded videos for internal education.
Created incident management stats gathering and visualisation systems.
Introduced a few SRE concepts to the company.

work.name: Svyaznoy Zagruzka
work.summary: Svyaznoy Zagruzka (~40 employees) is a telecommunication content provider, and it powers services that send and receive SMS messages and USSD requests for partners. I handled client integration and support. My day-to-day activity was monitoring and troubleshooting a set of applications with investigations in the network on the application level. Wireshark and SQL console were my best friends. I wrote code in Bash, Perl, and Python, mostly to automate routine tasks.

work.name: Russian Federation Army
work.summary: I served in the army for one year after obtaining my university degree.

work.name: BioChemMack (medical equipment dealer)
work.summary: Seventy employees company, BioChemMack, resells medical equipment. I've created and populated a wiki with information about internal infrastructure, migrated a primary server from the old CentOS version to Ubuntu, improved company network architecture, and participated in medical equipment users' technical support.

work.name: FS Group (metal reseller)
work.summary: I was a one-person army providing every IT service a small multi-location company needed. I've established a network setup, created documentation on company infrastructure, and participated in website development, SEO and advertising. Years later, I helped the company find contractors for these IT tasks and establish IT goals.
